comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: A group of Redmondite volunteer Non Commissioned Officers in full regalia!  I don't think I've seen anything like this before.  All patriotic and well meaning and caught out by the Rising in 1916 and the decision of their leaders to support Britain in WW1 in the hope of gaining Home Rule by peaceful means.  Many of them joined the war effort in Europe and lost their lives and many more changed over and took an active part in the war of independence.  They are surprisingly well equipped with rifles, those are Lee-Enfield Mark II riflles the standard issue to the British Army at that time though they are sporting Boer War bandoliers.

comment._content: A few weeks before this the colours that had been presented to the volunteers by Redmond had been burned along with a hundred uniforms in a fire at Hearne & company. Incidentally in March 1915 Hearne & Co. held a banquet in honour of their staff members who had enlisted in the British army, over 20 of them were National Volunteers. comment.author: 66941036@N05
comment._content: They are not in fact pig sticker bayonets (which were introduced in WW2), although I can see why corncrake68 thought that they were.  The visual appearance (like a needle) is because the rifles are viewed edge on and so what you are seeing is just the back edge of the bayonet.  They are in fact the original Lee Metford Rifle bayonets that in typical fashion were modified for the replacement Lee Enfield Rifle in order to save on cost.
